issues.title: iss claim
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
Should we explicitly note that the absence of an "iss" claim sets this draft apart from RFC7523 (where it is a required claim).

We may want to be more clear about the degree to which this is a profile (or extended profile) of RFC 7523 (related to the topic above, but maybe there is more - probably).

comments.author: arndt-s
comments.body:
I wouldn't say the absence of the `iss` claim is what sets this draft apart from 7523. In the end a lot of JWT-SVIDs carry it! Section 5.5 tries to cover that a bit and basically forbids the use of key distribution based on `iss` claim in the context of this spec.

---

Regarding the profiling:
- JWT-SVID profiles RFC7523
- X509-SVID profiles RFC7521

If we don't profile RFC7523 we need to talk a lot about JWT processing, etc. which I'm not sure we want to duplicate.

issues.title: Should we point people that want to pursue this approach to raw RFC7523?
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
I want to say yes... but... the key distribution is not described in RFC 7523. So, some options:

1. Bump readers to RFC 7523 and instruct them to use the key distribution mechanisms in this draft.
2. Bump them to RFC 7523 and let them "build their own adventure" for key distribution.
3. Provide guidance on what to do with the "iss" claim.

comments.author: arndt-s
comments.body:
1. is basically this draft, it uses RFC7523 + restricts key distribution
2. that's the current approach
3. I don't think we should put that in scope of this document. No reason to describe key distro outside of SPIFFE if this spec is about SPIFFE.

issues.title: Cover "Certificate-Bound Access Tokens" part of RFC 8705
issues.author: dagdagdag83
issues.body:
The company that I work for is implementing a workload identity pattern (inspired heavily by WIMSE WG) for securing service to service communication. One of the biggest benefits that we are leveraging is using Istio mTLS certificates (which are roughly SPIFFE-compatible) to get Certificate-Bound Access Tokens. This is something you get for "free" when implementing RFC 8705.

IMO this specification should be more explicit about the ability to get certificate-bound tokens, because in effect these tokens are actually **workload-bound** (via SPIFFE ID) which is a huge security benefit. 

The only modification we'd had to make for RFC 8705 is the following:

1) We add a new cnf claim:
```
  "cnf":{
    "x5t#S256": "87abe78e185a0c5ee193bf1e34b36bbf43f47178850871b30225e23542b7d503",
    "x5s#SPIFFE": "spiffe://cluster.local/ns/namespace/sa/default"
  }
```
The `x5s#SPIFFE` is intended to reference to SPIFFE ID, the reason for that is because istio rotates mTLS certificates very quickly so we didn't want to rely on only the `x5t#S256` claim to validate the binding.

2) RFC 8705 expects that the leaf cert itself or thumbprint is saved (or available at least) to the AS so that it can verify it.
For the same reason as above (rapid rotation) we don't do this. We only store the SPIFFE ID, then we use the root public CA (which Istio publishes) to verify the cert chain itself.

Then following that, any of our APIs that gets these tokens will pretty much validate the certificate-binding per RFC 8705.

```
Traditional OAuth client authentication typically relies on client secrets or private key JWT authentication, both require an out of band distribution of secret material to the OAuth client. The SPIFFE profile for client authentication enables seamless integration between SPIFFE-based and OAuth-based systems, allowing applications to leverage both ecosystems without requiring additional credential management. It also enables a more secure authentication method by leveraging cryptographically verifiable credentials rather than shared secrets.
```

## Pull Request Overview

This PR refines the SPIFFE trust bundle sections by prioritizing the SPIFFE Bundle Endpoint and presenting other methods—including the system trust store—as discouraged alternatives.

- Renamed and expanded the main section to “SPIFFE Key Distribution and Validation.”
- Promoted the Bundle Endpoint and restructured SPIFFE Workload API, manual configuration, system trust store, and JWT-SVID `iss` as “methods to avoid.”
- Added a new “Using the system trust store” subsection detailing its risks.

comments.body: The section anchor 'spiffe-bundle-validation' no longer matches the updated title; consider updating the anchor (e.g., 'spiffe-key-distribution-and-validation') for consistency.

Use 'an update' instead of 'a update' to correct the article before a vowel sound.
```suggestion
The SPIFFE Workload API allows workloads to retrieve a trust bundle from SPIFFE. It requires the authorization server to be part of a SPIFFE trust domain and be considered a workload within it. The authors acknowledge that using the SPIFFE Workload API can reduce the time an update to the bundle is received by the authorization server.
```

Typo in 'mechnism'; should be 'mechanism'.
```suggestion
In addition to the trust bundle of the trust domain the workload resides in, the SPIFFE Workload API also allows to retrieve trust bundles from federated trust domains. This mechanism moves trust establishment away from the authorization server to the SPIFFE configuration and is NOT RECOMMENDED and more explicit configuration SHOULD be maintained.
```

Consider using 'system trust store' or 'system's trust store' for correct grammar and clarity.
```suggestion
X509-SVIDs MUST NOT be validated using the system's trust store. The SPIFFE ID carried in the URI SAN is not a verified attribute in the broader X.500 ecosystem and using the system trust store as trust anchor would allow ANY certificate authority in it to issue a X509-SVID for ANY SPIFFE-ID which would be considered trusted. In comparison: using SPIFFE-native validation methods restricts the signing of SPIFFE-IDs to the corresponding trust domain signing keys.
```

reviews.author: copilot-pull-request-reviewer
reviews.body:
## Pull Request Overview

This PR refines the SPIFFE trust establishment guidelines by recommending the SPIFFE Bundle Endpoint over the Workload API and adding an alternative method using the system trust store. Key changes include certificate data updates, renaming and restructuring of sections, and the inclusion of an example configuration for the SPIFFE Bundle Endpoint.

comments.body: The comment indicates a certificate mismatch issue between the bundle and the X509-SVID; please verify and update the certificate data to ensure consistency.
"The SPIFFE Bundle Endpoint exposes the signing keys for X509 and JWT-SVIDs over HTTP via a JSON Web Key Set according to {{RFC7517}}."
"Server authentication on this endpoint is available in two flavors. For the sake of interoperability, in context of this specification the WebPKI flavor MUST be used."

On second reading, I think it's fine to put the system trust store in "methods to avoid", and clarify the proper method here. In reference to our offline discussion: This section doesn't say anything about scoping down the trust store. But the client doesn't have the information to know how to do that. That's really up to the bundle endpoint.

"The SPIFFE ID carried in the URI SAN is rarely a verifiable attribute in the broader X.509 ecosystem. Using the system trust store as trust anchor would allow ANY certificate authority in it to issue a trusted X509-SVID for ANY SPIFFE ID."

Instead of:

The authors acknowledge that using the SPIFFE Workload API can reduce the time an update of the bundle is received by the authorization server.

how about:

Using the SPIFFE Workload API reduces the latency between an update to the trust bundle and the time the authorization server receives the update.
Is this a pattern we want to encourage?

This seems overly restrictive - not sure about the "NOT RECOMMENDED" here - I think it comes down to the rust relationships that the authorization server accept. I can imagine that if I have both an OAuth server and a SPIFFE deployment, I would be OK to say "I trust the SPIFFE deployment, and accept all the trust relationships it establishes" - it's a risk decision that is deployment specific.

A better way to address this is to highlight the risk that a SPIFFE deployment may contain multiple federation relationships, and as a result, the OAuth deployment SHOULD make a conscious decision on whether to allow federation. The riskd ecision belongs to the deployment.
Add a sentence on why - e.g. the iss claim points to a SPIFFE issues and cannot normally be resolved or something similar.
